p.s: In Sonnet 138, written by William Shakespeare, the speaker introduces the train of thought by describing his relationship to his beloved.
In the first quatrain he explains that he is aware of the lies of his beloved person.
EventhoughEven though the narrator knows about his partner lying, he still burts and accepts his/her behavior.
In the following quatrain, the speaker explains that he is also not completlycompletely honest.
The partner also pretends not to know about the narrator's age, acting like he is young.
One can detect, that both are hiding the truth, pretending that they do not know the real age of eachothereach other.
In the last quatrain, the act of lying is questioned.
However, it does not demonstrate a negative connotation.
Quite the reverse, with the turning point, the Volta in line 9, the speaker claims that this false trust is helpful and existential, as love is against age differences.
The age difference is problematic for love, which is why it is acceptable to be unhonest.
Lastly, in the final couplet, the sonnet is ending with the lovers laying together and sharing the same lie and feeling of unhonesty.
It bonds the two and together they express the same feeling, the same problem, but rather than being completlycompletely honest, they secretly hide true emotions from each other.
To sum it up, the persona of the poem talks about his relationship and the lies that are bothering in the situation.
However, he is still convinced that this way of living with his love is better for them.
